I think Jeff has hit the nail on the head, I too would like to be
able to get some feedback when the number of asserts has changed
for the same reasons.

Seems to me that the simplest thing that could possibly work is
to count the asserts.

+1

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jeff Langr [mailto:JLangr@...]

> Subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
>
>
> I have a passing interesting in seeing an assertion count in JUnit, but I
> could and do live without it just fine.  My reason seems to be different
> from any of the others I've seen.
>
> I don't give a hoot about the total number of assertions for whatever
> metrics purposes.  I do care about doing test-first coding appropriately.
>
> That means: code some context, code an assert.
> Make sure the assert fails.  Fix the assert.
> Add another assert to the same test method.
> Repeat until done with all things that assert against
> the given context for the test method.
>
> My problem is that my memory is poor, and I get
> distracted.  I just coded an assert and compiled.
> Or did I really compile?
> Drat, I forgot.
> Did I just add a new assert to the body of tests or did I not?
>
> The count of assertions would be something visual that would change so I
> could get *feedback* and not have to trust myself.  It's part of
> the reason
> there is a count of tests, anyway.
>
> What if instead of being a count, it was a simple visual symbol
> that showed,
> for a given test class, that there is now a new assert that is
> being run for
> the first time?
> (could be a royal pain to figure out... consider if asserts are changed
> or deleted)
>
> Or am I just slower than the majority of developers?
>
